   56M with asthma, DM, HTN presenting with respiratory distress and
   pneumonia/ARDS from influenza A/H1N1.
   # Respiratory failure: Originally ARDS/sepsis combined w/ fluid
   overload and possible bacterial pneumonia. Pt had a trach placed.  Has
   been off sedating drips for several days and had been doing well on
   pressure support.  Has started on Methadone to try and decrease his
   tachypnea, instead of bolusing sedatives, and also as a wean from the
   sedation that he has been on for the past several weeks.
   - Continue methadone 10mg TID to address tachypnea
   - F/u ABG this afternoon
   - Trach mask trial later today
   - F/u cultures of blood, sputum, and urine, f/u mini-BAL
   - Will d/c ABx today as we have no clear source that we were treating
   - Nebulizer treatments and suctioning
   - Wean down FiO2
   #Fevers/leukocytosis: Fever curve and leukocytosis improved with
   antibiotics (on vanc, cipro and cefepime) and CV line removal. Had
   completed courses of Azithro, Peramivir, vanco and aztreonam for
   bacterial overgrowth of pneumonia, was then restarted on
   Vanc/Cefepime/Cipro.
   - Will d/c ABx as above as we have no clear source that we are
   treating.
   - Follow up all cultures, including catheter tip and mini-BAL
   # DM2: Was on insulin gtt until recently, but now switched to Glargine
   40U qhs and SSI. Has increasing SSI needs; now on tubefeeds
   - Glargine has been recently increased to 45 qhs
   - Watch BS's through the day and increase accordingly
   # Tachycardia: Previously appeared to have multifocal atrial
   tachycardia. Patient started previously on Lopressor; then held for
   tenuous clinical status.
   - monitor on telemetry
   # Anemia: Hematocrits stable for several days now after trending down
   on admission.  Will continue to monitor daily.
   -transfuse if below 21
   #PEG placement: Currently getting Novasource renal
   # Critical illness myopathy:
   - F/u PT consult
   Other stable issues:
    #Renal failure: Urine output and creatinine have improved.  Had
   component of ATN with muddy casts in urine.  Has really improved with
   treatment and improvement of ARDS.
   - Renal team has signed off
   - Cr within baseline
   # Eye redness and discharge: Per nursing, patient had contact in his
   right eye which was only removed the other day as there was no record
   that patient wore contacts. Unable to find contact in left eye.  Seen
   by ophthalmology who mentioned that contact was intentionally there.
   Also suggested some changes to his eye-drops and outpatient follow-up.
   Patient already has outpatient appointment set up.
   - Prednisolone and tobramycin drops to R eye as prescribed.
   - Artificial tears ointment to both eyes
   # Rash: Rash improved after zosyn d/c
d.  No signs of DRESS.  Did have
   some follicles which are improving.
   - Chlorhexadine wash on arms and legs to help prevent infection of
   follicles
   # Hypothyroidism: Per most recent d/c summary, Synthroid at 50mcg daily
   or 25 IV.  Continued here.
   #GERD: PPI
   FEN: No IVF, replete electrolytes PRN, renal tube feeds.
   Prophylaxis: Subcutaneous heparin; pneumoboots, PPI and bowel regimen
   Access: 1 peripherals, A-line. Placed order for PICC to be placed
   tomorrow, for antibiotic delivery.
   Code:  Full Code as discussed with parents.
   Communication: Father and mother who are in to see him daily.
   Disposition: Pending improved respiratory status.
   ICU Care
   Nutrition:

Summary: The patient is a 56-year-old male with a history of asthma, diabetes mellitus (DM), and hypertension. He presented with respiratory distress and pneumonia/ARDS from influenza A/H1N1. The patient's medical complications include respiratory failure, fevers/leukocytosis, diabetes mellitus type 2 (DM2), tachycardia, anemia, critical illness myopathy, renal failure, eye redness and discharge, rash, hypothyroidism, gastroesophageal reflux disease (GERD), and deep vein thrombosis (DVT) prophylaxis.

Summary:
The patient is a 56-year-old male with a history of asthma, diabetes mellitus (DM), and hypertension who presented with respiratory distress and pneumonia/ARDS from influenza A/H1N1. The patient has been in the ICU and has shown improvement in his respiratory status, but still requires frequent suctioning of thick secretions. The patient's fever curve and leukocytosis have improved with antibiotics, and the antibiotics have been discontinued. The patient's blood glucose levels have been stable, and he has started receiving tube feeds through a percutaneous endoscopic gastrostomy (PEG) tube.

The patient's medical complications include:

1. Respiratory failure: The patient was initially on mechanical ventilation but is now tolerating a tracheostomy collar well. He is mildly tachypneic when interacting with people but has a reduced respiratory rate. The plan is to wean off methadone and continue nebulizer treatments and suctioning.

2. Hypoglycemia: The patient experienced hypoglycemia overnight but is now stable. His insulin dose has been reduced, and he will be monitored for blood sugar levels throughout the day.

3. Alkalosis, respiratory: The patient has respiratory alkalosis due to hyperventilation.

4. Pulmonary edema: The patient's chest X-ray suggests fluid overload or congestive heart failure (CHF).

5. Fever (hypothermia, pyrexia, not fever of unknown origin): The

   56M with asthma, DM, HTN presenting with respiratory distress and
   pneumonia/ARDS from influenza A/H1N1.
   # Respiratory failure: Originally ARDS/sepsis combined w/ fluid
   overload and possible bacterial pneumonia. Pt had a trach placed.  Has
   been off sedating drips for several days and had been doing well on
   pressure support.  Has started on Methadone to try and decrease his
   tachypnea, instead of bolusing sedatives, and also as a wean from the
   sedation that he has been on for the past several weeks.
   - Continue methadone 10mg TID to address tachypnea
   - F/u ABG this afternoon
   - Trach mask trial later today
   - F/u cultures of blood, sputum, and urine, f/u mini-BAL
   - Will d/c ABx today as we have no clear source that we were treating
   - Nebulizer treatments and suctioning
   - Wean down FiO2
   #Fevers/leukocytosis: Fever curve and leukocytosis improved with
   antibiotics (on vanc, cipro and cefepime) and CV line removal. Had
   completed courses of Azithro, Peramivir, vanco and aztreonam for
   bacterial overgrowth of pneumonia, was then restarted on
   Vanc/Cefepime/Cipro.
   - Will d/c ABx as above as we have no clear source that we are
   treating.
   - Follow up all cultures, including catheter tip and mini-BAL
   # DM2: Was on insulin gtt until recently, but now switched to Glargine
   40U qhs and SSI. Has increasing SSI needs; now on tubefeeds
   - Glargine has been recently increased to 45 qhs
   - Watch BS's through the day and increase accordingly
   # Tachycardia: Previously appeared to have multifocal atrial
   tachycardia. Patient started previously on Lopressor; then held for
   tenuous clinical status.
   - monitor on telemetry
   # Anemia: Hematocrits stable for several days now after trending down
   on admission.  Will continue to monitor daily.
   -transfuse if below 21
   #PEG placement: Currently getting Novasource renal
   # Critical illness myopathy:
   - F/u PT consult
   Other stable issues:
    #Renal failure: Urine output and creatinine have improved.  Had
   component of ATN with muddy casts in urine.  Has really improved with
   treatment and improvement of ARDS.
   - Renal team has signed off
   - Cr within baseline
   # Eye redness and discharge: Per nursing, patient had contact in his
   right eye which was only removed the other day as there was no record
   that patient wore contacts. Unable to find contact in left eye.  Seen
   by ophthalmology who mentioned that contact was intentionally there.
   Also suggested some changes to his eye-drops and outpatient follow-up.
    Patient already has outpatient appointment set up.
   - Prednisolone and tobramycin drops to R eye as prescribed.
   - Artificial tears ointment to both eyes
   # Rash: Rash improved after zosyn d/c
d.  No signs of DRESS.  Did have
   some follicles which are improving.
   - Chlorhexadine wash on arms and legs to help prevent infection of
   follicles
   # Hypothyroidism: Per most recent d/c summary, Synthroid at 50mcg daily
   or 25 IV.  Continued here.
   #GERD: PPI
   FEN: No IVF, replete electrolytes PRN, renal tube feeds.
   Prophylaxis: Subcutaneous heparin; pneumoboots, PPI and bowel regimen
   Access: 1 peripherals, A-line. Placed order for PICC to be placed
   tomorrow, for antibiotic delivery.
   Code:  Full Code as discussed with parents.
   Communication: Father and mother who are in to see him daily.
   Disposition: Pending improved respiratory status.
Summary:
Summary of Progress Note:
The patient is a 56-year-old male with a medical history of asthma, diabetes mellitus, and hypertension. He presented with respiratory distress and pneumonia caused by influenza A/H1N1. The patient was initially diagnosed with acute respiratory distress syndrome (ARDS), sepsis without organ dysfunction, and fluid overload. He underwent tracheostomy placement and has been on mechanical ventilation support.

Current Assessment:
The patient's condition has improved significantly. He is now off sedating drips and is on methadone to decrease tachypnea. An ABG test showed pH 7.44, which indicates respiratory alkalosis. The patient has been doing well on pressure support. He will continue to have a trach mask trial later today, and his cultures of blood, sputum, and urine will be followed up, along with a mini-BAL. Antibiotics will be discontinued as there is no clear source of infection.

Diagnoses and Plan:
1. Hypoglycemia: The patient's blood sugar levels are being monitored, and Glargine has been decreased to 35U qhs due to low blood sugars throughout the day.
2. Diabetes Mellitus Type II: The patient was previously on insulin gtt but has been switched to Glargine 40U qhs and SSI. His insulin needs are increasing, and he is now on tube feeds.
3. Alkalosis, Respiratory: The patient's ABG

Summary:
Summary:
The patient is a 56-year-old male with a history of asthma, diabetes mellitus, and hypertension. He presented with respiratory distress and pneumonia/ARDS due to influenza A/H1N1. The patient is currently in the ICU recovering from ARDS. He has been weaned off antibiotics and is afebrile. The patient is tolerating a tracheostomy collar well, but still has mild tachypnea. He will continue methadone to address tachypnea and have a follow-up ABG this afternoon. The patient's fever curve and leukocytosis improved with antibiotics and central venous line removal. His blood cultures, sputum cultures, and mini-BAL cultures are pending. The patient's diabetes mellitus type II is stable, but he experienced mild hypoglycemia overnight. He was restarted on tube feeds and his blood sugars will be monitored throughout the day. The patient had anemia, but hematocrits are now stable. A PEG placement was done. The patient may have critical illness myopathy, and a physical therapy consult has been requested. The patient's renal failure has improved with treatment and improvement of ARDS. His urine output and creatinine have improved, and the renal team has signed off. The patient had eye redness and discharge, possibly due to contact lens use, and was seen by ophthalmology. He was prescribed prednisolone and tobramycin drops for his right

   # Respiratory failure:  Now on trach collar and tolerating well.

   down to 12-13.  Will start to wean methadone.  Now off of antibiotics
   and afebrile.  Still requiring frequent suctioning of thick secretions,
   but has a good cough.  FIO2 weaned down maximally to 35-40%.
   - Continue to wean methadone from 7.5mg TID to 20mg once daily
   - Continue nebulizer treatments and suctioning
   .
   #Fevers/leukocytosis: Fever curve and leukocytosis improved with
   antibiotics (on vanc, cipro and cefepime) and CV line removal. Had
   completed courses of Azithro, Peramivir, vanco and aztreonam for
   bacterial overgrowth of pneumonia, was then restarted on
   Vanc/Cefepime/Cipro, which was stopped yesterday b/c there was no clear
   source for his recent fevers.
   - follow-up remaining pending cultures; NTD
   # DM2: Mildly hypoglycemic overnight, now stable.  Recently restarted
   tubefeeds, which are now at goal.

   - Monitor BS's less frequently, q6h
   .

   .
   # Tachycardia: Previously appeared to have multifocal atrial
   tachycardia. Patient started previously on Lopressor; then held for

   - monitor on telemetry
   .
   # Anemia: Hematocrits stable for several days now after trending down

   -transfuse if below 21

d.  No signs of DRESS.  Did have

   - Chlorhexadine wash on arms and legs to help prevent infection of

Summary:
Based on the provided progress note, the patient is a 56-year-old male with a medical history of asthma, diabetes mellitus, and hypertension. He presented with respiratory distress and pneumonia/acute respiratory distress syndrome (ARDS) due to influenza A/H1N1.

The patient's current condition is as follows:
1. Respiratory failure: The patient is now on a tracheostomy collar and tolerating well. He is mildly tachypneic when interacting with people but has a reduced respiratory rate of 12-13 breaths per minute. FiO2 has been weaned down to 35-40%.
2. Fevers/leukocytosis: The patient's fever curve and leukocytosis improved with antibiotics. He completed courses of Azithromycin, Peramivir, vancomycin, and aztreonam for bacterial overgrowth of pneumonia, and then restarted on vanc/cefepime/cipro, which was stopped yesterday since there was no clear source for his recent fevers.
3. Diabetes Mellitus Type II (DM2): The patient experienced mild hypoglycemia overnight but is now stable. He has restarted tube feeds, which are now at goal. Glargine has been reduced to 35 units QHS. Blood glucose has stabilized, and the patient will be monitored less frequently, q6h.
4. Tachycardia: The patient had multifocal atrial tachycardia

The patient is a 56-year-old male with a history of asthma, diabetes mellitus, and hypertension presenting with respiratory distress and pneumonia/ARDS from influenza A/H1N1. The patient has been in the ICU for an extended period and has several ongoing medical complications.

1. Respiratory failure: The patient is now on a tracheostomy collar and tolerating it well. He is mildly tachypneic but otherwise has a reduced respiratory rate. The plan is to wean him off the methadone, continue nebulizer treatments and suctioning, and gradually decrease the fraction of inspired oxygen (FiO2).

2. Fevers/leukocytosis: The patient's fever curve and leukocytosis improved with antibiotics (vancomycin, cefepime, and ciprofloxacin) and central venous line removal. However, there is no clear source for his recent fevers. The antibiotics have been discontinued, and follow-up cultures are pending.

3. Diabetes mellitus type 2 (DM2): The patient was mildly hypoglycemic overnight but is now stable. He has restarted tube feeds, which are at goal. Glargine dosage has been reduced to 35 units at bedtime, and blood sugar levels will be monitored throughout the day tomorrow.

4. Tachycardia: The patient previously had multifocal atrial tachycardia. He was started on Lopressor but it was

The patient's review of systems is unchanged from admission except for cough and no dyspnea. 

The patient has a history of diabetes mellitus type II, renal failure, pneumonia, sepsis without organ dysfunction, and acute respiratory distress syndrome (ARDS). 

Laboratory results show leukocytosis with a white blood cell count of 887 K/uL, elevated blood glucose levels, and altered liver function tests.

   ICU Care
   56M with asthma, DM, HTN presenting with respiratory distress and
   pneumonia/ARDS from influenza A/H1N1.
   # Respiratory failure:  Now on trach collar and tolerating well.
   Mildly tachypneic when interacting with people, but otherwise has RR
   down to 12-13.  Will start to wean methadone.  Now off of antibiotics
   and afebrile.  Still requiring frequent suctioning of thick secretions,
   but has a good cough.  FIO2 weaned down maximally to 35-40%.
   - Continue to wean methadone from 7.5mg TID to 20mg once daily
   - Continue nebulizer treatments and suctioning
   .
   #Fevers/leukocytosis: Fever curve and leukocytosis improved with
   antibiotics (on vanc, cipro and cefepime) and CV line removal. Had
   completed courses of Azithro, Peramivir, vanco and aztreonam for
   bacterial overgrowth of pneumonia, was then restarted on
   Vanc/Cefepime/Cipro, which was stopped yesterday b/c there was no clear
   source for his recent fevers.
   - follow-up remaining pending cultures; NTD
   # DM2: Mildly hypoglycemic overnight, now stable.  Recently restarted
   tubefeeds, which are now at goal.
   Glargine reduced to 35units QHS.   Blood glucose has stabilized.
   - Monitor BS's less frequently, q6h
   .
   Less active/resolved problems:
   .
   # Tachycardia: Previously appeared to have multifocal atrial
   tachycardia. Patient started previously on Lopressor; then held for
   tenuous clinical status.
   - monitor on telemetry
   .
   # Anemia: Hematocrits stable for several days now after trending down
   on admission.  Will continue to monitor daily.
   -transfuse if below 21
   .
   # Thrombocytosis: patient has had stably high platelet counts, which is
   new on this admission and likely reactive.
   - monitor daily.
   .
   #PEG placement: Currently getting Novasource renal
   .
   # Critical illness myopathy:
   - F/u PT consult
   .
    #Renal failure: Urine output and creatinine have improved.  Had
   component of ATN with muddy casts in urine.  Improved with treatment
   and improvement of ARDS.  Renal team has signed off.  Cr within
   baseline.
   .
   # Eye redness and discharge: Per nursing, patient had contact in his
   right eye which was only removed the other day as there was no record
   that patient wore contacts. Unable to find contact in left eye.  Seen
   by ophthalmology who mentioned that contact was intentionally there.
   Patient already has outpatient appointment set up.
   - Prednisolone and tobramycin drops to R eye as prescribed.
   - Artificial tears ointment to both eyes
   # Rash: Rash improved after zosyn d/c
d.  No signs of DRESS.  Did have
   some follicles which are improving.
   - Chlorhexadine wash on arms and legs to help prevent infection of
   follicles
   # Hypothyroidism: Per most recent d/c summary, Synthroid at 50mcg daily
   or 25 IV.  Continued here.
   #GERD: PPI
   FEN: No IVF, replete electrolytes PRN, renal tube feeds.  Speech and
   swallow eval and trach valve eval today.
   Prophylaxis: Subcutaneous heparin; pneumoboots, PPI and bowel regimen.
   D/C PPI now that pt not intubated.
   Access: 1 peripheral, A-line. Mid-line (was supposed to be PICC, but
   would not advance fully).  Plan to pull A-line today.
   Code:  Full Code as discussed with parents.
   Communication: Father and mother who are in to see him daily.
   Disposition: Pending improved secretions.  Being screened for rehab.
   ICU Care

Summary:
The patient is a 56-year-old male with a history of asthma, diabetes mellitus (DM), and hypertension. He presented with respiratory distress and pneumonia/ARDS caused by influenza A/H1N1. The patient has been in the ICU for an extended period and has multiple medical complications. 

Potential Medical Complications:
1. Respiratory Failure: The patient was initially on a tracheostomy collar and required respiratory support. Although he is tolerating well now, there is still a risk of respiratory failure due to his underlying conditions and the possibility of recurrent infections.

2. Pneumonia/Others: The patient had pneumonia/ARDS initially and received appropriate antibiotics. However, there is still a risk of developing other types of pneumonia or respiratory infections due to his compromised lung function and prolonged ICU stay.

3. Sepsis: The patient had fevers and leukocytosis, which improved with antibiotics. Although the recent fever curve is stable, there is still a risk of sepsis due to his immunocompromised state and potential sources of infection.

4. Diabetes Mellitus (DM) Type II: The patient has DM type II and experienced hypoglycemia. It is essential to monitor his blood glucose levels closely to maintain stable glycemic control.

5. Hyperglycemia: The patient also had episodes of hyperglycemia, indicating uncontrolled diabetes. Regular monitoring and management of blood glucose levels are necessary.

6. Alkalosis, Respir

Summary:
Summary:
The patient is a 56-year-old male with a history of asthma, diabetes mellitus (DM), and hypertension. He was admitted to the ICU due to respiratory distress and pneumonia/acute respiratory distress syndrome (ARDS) caused by influenza A/H1N1. The patient has been receiving various treatments and interventions, including tracheostomy, mechanical ventilation, antibiotics, and nutritional support.

Potential Medical Complications:
1. Hypoglycemia: The patient experienced mild hypoglycemia overnight, which requires close monitoring of blood glucose levels.
2. Diabetes Mellitus Type II (DM2): The patient has been restarted on tubefeeds, which are now at goal, and Glargine has been reduced to 35 units QHS. Blood glucose has stabilized/improved, so regular monitoring of blood sugar is necessary.
3. Alkalosis, respiratory: The patient has mild respiratory alkalosis, which may require further evaluation and management.
4. Pulmonary Edema: Although not explicitly mentioned, the patient's history of ARDS and pneumonia suggests a potential risk for pulmonary edema.
5. Fever (hypothermia, pyrexia, not fever of unknown origin): The patient had fevers initially, but they have improved with antibiotics. It is important to follow up on remaining pending cultures.
6. Tachycardia, other: The patient had multifocal atrial tachycardia, and his heart rate is within an appropriate range.

   Assessment and Plan
   56M with asthma, DM, HTN presenting with respiratory distress and
   pneumonia/ARDS from influenza A/H1N1.
   .
   # Respiratory failure:  Now on trach collar and tolerating well.
   Mildly tachypneic when interacting with people, but otherwise has RR
   down to 12-13.  Will start to wean methadone.  Now off of antibiotics
   and afebrile.  Still requiring frequent suctioning of thick secretions,
   but has a good cough.  FIO2 weaned down maximally to 35-40%.
   - Methadone at 5 mg TID.  Will continue to wean at rehab
   - Continue nebulizer treatments and suctioning
   .
   #Fevers/leukocytosis: Fever curve and leukocytosis improved with
   antibiotics (on vanc, cipro and cefepime) and CV line removal. Had
   completed courses of Azithro, Peramivir, vanco and aztreonam for
   bacterial overgrowth of pneumonia, was then restarted on
   Vanc/Cefepime/Cipro, which was stopped yesterday b/c there was no clear
   source for his recent fevers.  All cultures have been negative, no
   longer having fevers.
   .
   # DM2: Mildly hypoglycemic overnight, now stable.  Recently restarted
   tubefeeds, which are now at goal.
   Glargine reduced to 35units QHS.   Blood glucose has
   stabilized/improved.
   - continue sliding scale at rehab
   .
   # Muddy-brown wax in outer ear canal (right):
   - cipro ear drops, 7 day course, day #1 = [**12-29**]
   .
   Less active/resolved problems:
   .
   # Tachycardia: Previously appeared to have multifocal atrial
   tachycardia. Patient started previously on Lopressor; then held for
   tenuous clinical status. Continue to hold the lopressor, as HR
   appropriate range.  Patient with abnormal runs of MAT again this
   morning.
   - restart lopressor at rehab and titrate to HR<80 and SBP >100
   .
   # Anemia: Hematocrits stable for several days now after trending down
   on admission.  No longer in need of transfusions.
   .
   # Thrombocytosis: patient has had stably high platelet counts, which is
   new on this admission and likely reactive. Patient no longer in need of
   platelets
   .
   #PEG placement: Currently getting Novasource renal
   .
   # Critical illness myopathy:
   - continue PT at rehab center
   .
    #Renal failure: Urine output and creatinine have improved.  Had
   component of ATN with muddy casts in urine.  Improved with treatment
   and improvement of ARDS.  Renal team has signed off.  Cr within
   baseline.
   .
   # Eye redness and discharge: Per nursing, patient had contact in his
   right eye which was only removed the other day as there was no record
   that patient wore contacts. Unable to find contact in left eye.  Seen
   by ophthalmology who mentioned that contact was intentionally there.
   Patient already has outpatient appointment set up.
   - Prednisolone and tobramycin drops to R eye as prescribed.  To be
   continued at rehab until follows up with ophthamology
   - Artificial tears ointment to both eyes as needed
   - Put outpatient appointment with ophtho into the D/C planning.
   .
   # Rash: Rash improved after zosyn d/c
d.  No signs of DRESS.  Did have
   some follicles which are improving.
   - Chlorhexadine wash on arms and legs to help prevent infection of
   follicles
   .
   # Hypothyroidism: Per most recent d/c summary, Synthroid at 50mcg daily
   or 25 IV.  Continued here. TSH normal, continue dose as is.
   .
   # GERD: restart PPI.
    .
   FEN: No IVF, replete electrolytes PRN, renal tube feeds.  Patient with
   trach and now with PMV placed; needs adjustment (cough resulted in
   exhalation of stream of air) so f/u with speech & swallow again today
   for PMV adjustment. Check with nutrition re; iron deficiency.
   Prophylaxis: Subcutaneous heparin; pneumoboots, bowel regimen, PPI.
   Access: Mid-line. (Peripheral IV and A-line have been pulled).
   Code:  Full Code as discussed with parents.
   Communication: Father and mother who are in to see him daily.
   Disposition: Pending improved secretions.  Being moved to rehab at Mt
   Sinaii
Summary:
Summary:
The patient is a 56-year-old male with a history of asthma, diabetes mellitus (DM), and hypertension (HTN) who presented with respiratory distress and pneumonia/ARDS due to influenza A/H1N1. The patient has been in the ICU and has shown improvement. The patient is now on a tracheostomy collar, tolerating well, and has a good cough. The patient's fever curve and leukocytosis have improved with antibiotics, and the patient is no longer febrile. The patient's DM2 is stable, and tubefeeds are at goal. The patient's muddy-brown wax in the outer ear canal is being treated with cipro ear drops. The patient previously had tachycardia, anemia, thrombocytosis, PEG placement, critical illness myopathy, renal failure, eye redness and discharge, rash, hypothyroidism, and GERD. These conditions have either resolved or are being managed appropriately. The patient is scheduled for rehabilitation at Mount Sinai and will have follow-up appointments for various conditions. 

Potential Medical Complications:
1. Respiratory failure: The patient is still requiring frequent suctioning of thick secretions, which can lead to further respiratory distress if not managed properly.
2. Infection: Although the patient's fever curve and leukocytosis have improved with antibiotics, there is still a risk of developing new infections due to the immunocompromised state caused by AR

4. Muddy-brown wax in the outer ear canal (right): Cipro ear drops will be used for a 7-day course starting on [**12-29**].

5. Tachycardia: The patient previously had multifocal atrial tach
